metadata.title: Global Geometry of Multichannel Sparse Blind Deconvolution on the Sphere
metadata.author: Yanjun Li, Yoram Bresler
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: Multichannel blind deconvolution is the problem of recovering an unknown signal f and multiple unknown channels xi from convolutional measurements yi = xi f (i = 1, 2, . . . , N ). We consider the case where the xi’s are sparse, and convolution with f is invertible. Our nonconvex optimization formulation solves for a filter h on the unit sphere that produces sparse output yi h. Under some technical assumptions, we show that all local minima of the objective function correspond to the inverse filter of f up to an inherent sign and shift ambiguity, and all saddle points have strictly negative curvatures. This geometric structure allows successful recovery of f and xi using a simple manifold gradient descent algorithm with random initialization. Our theoretical findings are complemented by numerical experiments, which demonstrate superior performance of the proposed approach over the previous methods.

highlights: The resulting problem is termed multichannel sparse blind deconvolution (MSBD)

In addition to the sparsity prior on the channels {xi}iN=1, we impose, without loss of generality, the constraint that f has unit 2 norm, i.e., f is on the unit sphere. (This eliminates the scaling ambiguity inherent in the multichannel blind deconvolution problem.) We show that our sparsity promoting objective function has a nice geometric landscape on the the unit sphere: (S1) all local minima correspond to signed shifted versions of the desired solution, and (S2) the objective function is strongly convex in neighborhoods of the local minima, and has strictly negative curvature directions in neighborhoods of local maxima and saddle points

Our analysis consists of three parts: (1) Geometric structure of EL : We first bound minz: z =1, z⊥h z EHL (h)z, which is strictly positive near its local minima, and strictly negative near all other stationary points
We study the geometric structure of multichannel sparse blind deconvolution over the unit sphere

Our theoretical analysis reveals that local minima of a sparsity promoting smooth objective function correspond to signed shifted version of the ground truth, and saddle points have strictly negative curvatures
Studying the effect of subsampling on the geometric structure of multichannel sparse blind deconvolution is an interesting problem for future work

summary: The resulting problem is termed multichannel sparse blind deconvolution (MSBD).

Unlike the second order methods in previous works [37, 35], we take advantage of recent advances in the analysis of first-order methods [38, 39], and prove that a simple manifold gradient descent algorithm, with random initialization and a fixed step size, can accurately recover a signed shifted version of the ground truth in polynomial time almost surely.
We assume that {xi}Ni=1 are random sparse vectors, and f is invertible: (A1) The channels {xi}iN=1 follow a Bernoulli-Rademacher model.

Our analysis consists of three parts: (1) Geometric structure of EL : We first bound minz: z =1, z⊥h z EHL (h)z, which is strictly positive near its local minima, and strictly negative near all other stationary points.
We use the manifold gradient descent algorithm studied by Lee et al [39].

Section 3, and some technical results in [38, 39], the following result gives a theoretical guarantee for manifold gradient descent for our formulation of MSBD: convergence to an accurate estimate of the true solution.

Theorem 4.1 and Corollary 4.2 show that, with a random initialization and a fixed step size, manifold gradient descent outputs, in polynomial time, a solution that is close to a signed and shifted version of the ground truth.

The empirical phase transitions suggest that, for sparsity level relatively small (e.g., θ < 0.16), there exist a constant c > 0 such that manifold gradient descent can recover a signed shifted version of the ground truth with N ≥ cnθ.

We compare manifold gradient descent with three blind calibration algorithms that solve MSBD in the frequency domain: (i) truncated power iteration [29] = e1 and x(i0) = 0); an off-the-grid algebraic method [53]; and an off-the-grid optimization approach [54].
By the phase transitions in Figure 5, manifold gradient descent and truncated power iteration are both successful when N ≥ 48 and s ≤ 8.
We study the geometric structure of multichannel sparse blind deconvolution over the unit sphere.

Our theoretical analysis reveals that local minima of a sparsity promoting smooth objective function correspond to signed shifted version of the ground truth, and saddle points have strictly negative curvatures.
Simultaneously recover the unknown signal and unknown channels from convolutional measurements using manifold gradient descent with a random initialization.
Studying the effect of subsampling on the geometric structure of multichannel sparse blind deconvolution is an interesting problem for future work.
